title: Senior Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jun 2013
Interview Descriptions:
Saw a job posting for a senior software engineer position at one of the research labs at UCLA. Applied and received an email asking me to give them a couple of availability to go on-site for the interview. I showed up at the agreed upon time all ready to go.

The person I had been in contact with was not available that date. Another staff member there asked me to wait so she can find someone to interview me. After 10 minutes or so, one of the software engineers came out to greet me and took me to a conference room.

He started out by asking some standard questions like the type of work I've been doing and that type of software I've been working on. Towards the end of this part of the interview, he asked me what kind of salary was I looking for. Their job posting had a range from 80k to 150k and my range was right in the middle of that. I was pretty honest about what I wanted and what I'm making right now. He then threw out a number was way lower than my range and lower than what I am making right now. He then went out to explain because I didn't have Spring Framework experience, they couldn't offer me the senior software engineer position (by the way, Spring Framework wasn't even mentioned in the job posting). I came back by saying that it would be difficult to take a pay cut to take another job.

The atmosphere turned sour pretty quickly. He ended the questioning part by saying that he wanted me to write some code on paper to solve a graph problem. I sat there working on my code while he stepped away. I turned in my code after 15 minutes and had a little discussion about the part that I didn't get right. He then gave me a test consisted of 16 questions on paper and asked me to work on them, again, while he stepped away to do his things. At that point I felt like it wasn't much of an interview. It for sure felt like I was back at school taking a test. I answered all the questions, but didn't put too much efforts into making the answers as best as I could. I had a feeling that I wasn't going to get the job anyway and taking that test was just a formality. Maybe he needed something on paper so he can show that he did performed the interview.

I turned in the paper and thanked the interviewer for his time and that was the end of the interview.

The next day I wrote thank-you emails to both the person who initially contacted me and my interviewer. In the thank-you email to my interviewer, I wrote some addendum to my answer to one of the 16 questions, trying to make that particular answer more complete. Less than 10 minutes after sending that email, I got a reply from my interviewer basically saying that I wasn't a good fit for the position because I didn't answer all the questions right. But if I'm willing to accept a lower position (more importantly lower pay), he'd willing to continue the interview process. The person who initially contacted me never replied.

Again, I felt the entire process didn't show a lot of respect to the interviewee. There was no discussion and focus on my leadership and project management skills. The job description on the posting was either misleading, or my interviewer didn't know what they are. Another example: the post mentioned that PHP is one of the language that will be used. And I was told by my interviewer that PHP won't be used.
Interview Questions: What are the 4 core components of J2EE.

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview

title: Assistant Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jun 2013
Interview Descriptions:
The interview process began with a short phone interview. This consisted of basic skill and qualification questions. The interviewer also asked about general areas of personal interest and gave a brief overview of the type of work the position entailed and what to expect in terms of the work schedule.
The next interview was in person and more in depth. 
The entire interview process was a positive one. Most of the questions were fairly standard but necessary.  There were some personality and cultural "fit" questions peppered in as well.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time when it was difficult for you to admit you did not know something and ask for help. Would you have done anything differently?

title: Accounts Payable Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in May 2013
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview with a woman who had the personality of a wet mop. Lasted about ten minututes with her continuing her coldness and barely talking. I wish interviewers realized how bad this felt. As an interviewee, you are already nervous and on edge and it can be overwhelming at times. Then, people like this have a cavalier, unfriendly attitude that makes everything worse and you feel like you've had the wind knocked out of you by the end of the interview. Phone interviews in general are a joke and should be done away with. This interview was awful. WASTE OF TIME!!

title: Account Executive Interview

Questions were simple as he just asked "What do you know about Yelp/the position?" "Why do you want to work here?" His questions were fine, but he was EXTREMELY rude on the phone that took me very much off guard and nervous. Especially in terms of tone and attitude, which was a bit unprofessional, in my opinion. If you interview with him, just beware!
Interview Questions: He asked me if I knew who some basketball coach was from UCLA and when I answered no, his tone of voice became even more derogatory.

title: Resident Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UCLA
Interview Descriptions: ORL tries to make their interview process better every year, but usually it consists of a paper application, a class/group interview, and an individual interview. Everyone who's interested fills out an online application (paper application), and they select who will move on to the class. The class is advised by current Resident Directors and Assistants, and you talk about the RA role and you do group presentations. From this class, Resident Directors and RAs can get a better understanding of who the candidates are. Everyone who's taking the class gets an interview. During the interview, you go through a round robin interview process. There are usually five tables, and each table has a Resident Director and RA, and they ask you questions pertaining to different aspects of the Resident Assistant job. In the past years, the topics were programming, teamwork, community, policy enforcement, and self awareness. Everyone takes turns at each table, so you'll get a chance to answer questions for each topic.
Interview Questions: When was a time you enforced policy?

title: Helpdesk Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: Was the boss and 2 current helpdesk workers observing the interview. We communicated by email until the interview which took place in the conference room of the office. The boss was serious but not intimidating when asking questions.
Interview Questions: Let's say there was a dinosaur that lived millions of years ago, and that dinosaur drank some water and then later peed it out. If I were fill a cup of water from the cooler right now what are the chances that some of the water that the dinosaur drank is in the cup of water I have?

title: Senior Clerk Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: I dropped off my resume in person to my boss. I believe I was asked if I was available for an interview later that day. My boss and my supervisor were present. They explained the duties of the position. They asked me about my previous work experience. They asked me what my major was. They asked me how many hours a week I wanted to work.
Interview Questions: What skills or work experience did I have that prepared me for this position?

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Sept 2012
Interview Descriptions: Great - professors and students really seek a good match.  I spoke with several professors about my interests, and asked them questions about their research.  I tried to find areas of common interest, where we both got excited about a particular question of research - especially a question that can be answered through empirical study.  First you interview, then you submit an application.  The overall experience was good, if nerve-wracking.
Interview Questions: What are you interested in?  Why this school?  Which professors do you want to work with and why?  What do you want to do after graduate school?

title: Public Administration Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA in Aug 2012
Interview Descriptions:
I was first vetted on the phone. After they reviewed my application, I met with multiple department heads. The gave me a low offer at the very beginning and I had to negotiate. It resulted in a slight bump. I am glad that I always negotiate the first offer.

The whole process took about a month. Very typical. I would say that each department in UCLA does things differently. The only constant factor is that we all get paid on the low end of the market.
Interview Questions: Explain why you think your past job experience will help you succeed here?

title: Lab Assistant With Work Study Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UCLA (UCLA, CA) in Aug 2012
Interview Descriptions: I submitted my resume and cover letter through UCLA work study site. In the first week of class. I was contacted by the supervisors to setup a meeting and learn about the work place.
Interview Questions: What did you not like about your previous job?

title: Development Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at UCLA (UCLA, CA) in Aug 2012
Interview Descriptions: After a phone interview, I interviewed in person with my direct supervisor and was offered the position about one month later.
Interview Questions: I was asked to describe many specific examples of problem solving from previous jobs.

title: Associate Director of Communications Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jul 2012
Interview Descriptions: Started with a phone interview, then in person with about 8 staff members which lasted an hour, final interview was with the school's dean and lasted about 40 minutes. Phone interview was standard questions describing what you do and experience. A lengthier resume check basically. Staff interview was in a room with several staffers who each had asked questions - seemed very rehearsed. The deans interview was basically to see if he could get along with me! Seemed fairly simple and straight forward.
Interview Questions: Name some magazines that you read regularly?

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jul 2012
Interview Descriptions:
E-mail and Telephonic interview.
Interview was basically directed towards hiring position requirements and my background to solve those needs. Questions were mostly technical and my previous experiences. Apart for that general questions were asked to evaluate my work attitude, leadership and needs. I think I was evaluated if I have enough background experience to work in this position and my ability to satisfy the position needs.
Interview Questions: Nothing was very difficult for me.. It was general questions.

title: Assistant Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at UCLA (West Los Angeles, CA) in Jul 2012
Interview Descriptions: you need to bring your own funding, gave them a presentation, and wait, wait, wait....wait, wait, wait....wait, wait, wait,wait, wait, wait,wait, wait, wait...........If no further money, you must get it out right away. Not a good place to focus on research, strongly suggest: if you want find a tennue position that can focus on your research, it is better not come to UCLA. So tough here. NO money, no lab, no position....
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jun 2012
Interview Descriptions: Talk to the PI you're interested in and see if you guys are mutually compatible. At this point, you should have already been accepted into UCLA. It just becomes a matter of finding a lab which interests you.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to join this lab?

title: Student Work Study Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at UCLA (UCLA, CA) in Jun 2012
Interview Descriptions: Very relaxed. Asked me to go through my resume and explain the job function. The interviewers were very nice. They said they were very open to student schedules and my summer work study could turn into a school year one as well.
Interview Questions: Tell me your schedule for the school year?

title: Video Production Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions: Written application, interview with supervisor
Interview Questions: Explain a situation in which you worked with a team and solved a problem.

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions: I was searching for labs that worked on epigenetic regulation at UCLA, and I stumbled on the lab website of my current adviser. I contacted him by email to enquire about vacancies for postdoctoral fellows and attached my cover letter and CV. He responded within a day and asked to set up a phone interview. We spoke on the phone a week later, and that led to an in-person interview where the lab hosted me for an entire day. I got to present my work in a formal setting, speak individually to different lab members, and then go out to lunch with some of them. At the end of the day, I met with the lab head and I expressed my desire to join this lab, and he seemed happy enough with how the interview meant. He asked me to give him a week before he would let me know his decision, after which he contacted me to offer me the position.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself after your postdoctoral experience is over?

title: Administrative Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UCLA (Westwood, CA) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: Applied in early January, received a call two weeks later to come in for an interview.  Day of the interview sat down with two people, then met with another personal seperately.  Was then offered the job the very next day.  Very quick process and nice people.
Interview Questions: Tell me one last thing that will make me want to hire you....

title: Student Clerk Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UCLA in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: I first met with one of the counselors for ~30 minutes who asked me generic interview questions (Strengths, weaknesses, how I handle projects, biggest challenges, etc.) I then met with two members of clerical staff for ~5 minutes. I spoke with the mainly to get a feel of office culture and how I would fit in with the team.
Interview Questions: How do you handle deadlines/assignments?

title: Front Desk Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UCLA (UCLA, CA) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: Brought in to be interviewed by assistant manager and then called back for a second interview with the manager. Easy process, lots of applicants but a lot of openings as well. High turnover because they are largely unaccommodating. Work for sproul or De Neve if you can, they are much more lax. Rieber is the worst, Hedrick the second worst.
Interview Questions: What is your availability?

title: Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jan 2012
Interview Descriptions: Went around Anderson to ask for a job and a quarter later I heard back from a director and hired me for a part-time job.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself.

title: Staff Research Associate III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Nov 2011
Interview Descriptions: I was first interviewed by my immediate supervisor, followed by his supervisor. They both asked similar questions. They were mostly interested in my past work experience, what kind of computer and data analysis skills I had, the types of projects I had worked on, and my future career plans. The interview questions were fairly standard and not difficult to answer.
Interview Questions:
1. Past work experiences 
2. Future career plans
3. Computer skills

title: Math Reader Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at UCLA in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions: I didn't really have an interview. I submitted an application, went in to meet the boss, and got my assignment. Had to introduce myself to the professor and TA I was assigned to. The requirements for the job were simple because they were just classes in the department and they could've looked up qualifications in the system.
Interview Questions: What classes have you taken?

title: Work Study Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Aug 2011
Interview Descriptions: Submitted a resume, heard back within a weak.Simply went into the office, very informal, was selected for submitting previous work. One interview with a direct supervisor was done. Not much preparation needed. Keep your schedule relatively open for best chance.
Interview Questions: Q. How do you handle meeting new people?

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Aug 2011
Interview Descriptions:
For teaching some of the larger undergraduate life science classes there is no formal interview, you simply let the relevant administrator know you are interested in teaching one of the classes and what your qualifications are. If you attended UCLA as an undergraduate and took the class yourself it is a big help. Many of the jobs are preferentially given to graduate students in certain departments, so if you are outside one of those departments you will wait for an email confirming that there is an available position. Then there will be a large group meeting with administrators and the other TAs where a details are discussed and scheduling is hashed out. At this point you sign some agreements  and verify that you will be available to teach however many sections are required.

If you have no teaching experience then there is a class on how to be a good TA which is taught concurrently with your first teaching job. This is a relatively low-stress class and it would be hard to fail at this point since they've already committed to having you teach a class. You will learn basic teaching and administrative skills and also attend several seminars relating to sexual harassment and appropriate behavior between students and TAs.

For smaller classes taught by a single professor it is not uncommon to meet for an informal interview if you are not already familiar with the class and professor. Usually this happens at the professors office or an on campus coffee shop and is more focused on your knowledge of the subject and availability. Once again it helps to have taken the class yourself, but it is also common to TA a class taught by the professor whose lab you work in. If you have neither taken the class nor met the professor before it is unlikely you will find yourself in this position.
Interview Questions: Will you be able to fit 20 hours of teaching work in around your course load?

title: Clinical Instructor Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jul 2011
Interview Descriptions: I believe it was a brief phone interview and CV submission.  They just needed Psychologists to pair up with medical doctors to co-instruct a doctoring and clinical skills class for medical students.
Interview Questions: If I have experience teaching.

title: Administrative Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: They want you to stay as long as possible. Say that you plan to stay here for 5+ years and you'll get hired on the spot.
Interview Questions: How long do you plan to stay here?

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at UCLA in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed via skype as I am from Europe. It was quite straight forward, but I would advise to visit the lab/institution before signing a contract. It is difficult to get a realistic impression before meeting your employer in person.
Interview Questions: No real unexpected or difficult questions in regards to the job itself.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UCLA (UCLA, CA) in Jun 2011
Interview Descriptions: Emailing and asking basic questions in terms of chemistry.
Interview Questions: When are you available

title: Assistant Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in May 2011
Interview Descriptions: Grueling: two interviews with 3-5 psychologists or doctors each time. Some of them were very nice and the interview questions were appropriate and thoughtful. Others were disrespectful and rude. Overall, it left a very distasteful feeling for me. I did get called back for a second interview, but never went for the background check because I decided I didn't want to work for a hunch of pretentious people lacking compassion. Ironically, they told me I was the runner up for the position.
Interview Questions: Many, many questions. One question was why I had about a four month gap in work history. I answered the question honestly- that I had lost a pregnancy in my second trimester and needed time to recover. Interviewer did not like that answer. Also, they expected me to work long hours and required a master's, but then seemed put off that I didn't want a PhD.

title: Administrative Assistant III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Apr 2011
Interview Descriptions: Behavioral Interview Questions
Interview Questions: Standard questions. Some departments require a computer test.

title: ______ Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: There was only one interview with two supervisors. Questions were pretty ordinary for a clerical job. The hiring process was really quick. Work culture varies in terms of who (personality-wise) and where you get placed to work with.
Interview Questions: Explain your strengths and shortcomings, always really awkward to think about.

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA in Nov 2010
Interview Descriptions:
Submitted application online in November, got email invitation for phone interview in 2 weeks. Got the offer onsite and accepted the offer in 2 weeks after the interview.

Direct phone interview with your potential PI. As long as you can convince him/her that you are the right guy for the lab, you are in.
Interview Questions: This is only for optics major: Details in optics regarding the difference between temporal and spatial coherence.

title: Assistant Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at UCLA in Sept 2010
Interview Descriptions: No in site interview, only checked skills and experience by phone, email and referrals. Checked educational level. Contacted former employers by email and asked for detailed description of skills and experience. Received offer by emailed letter.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Senior Clerk/Event Planner Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Sept 2010
Interview Descriptions: Very simple. Went in and was asked about my hobbies and how well I knew the area. Ended talking with the interviewer for about an hour.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Jun 2010
Interview Descriptions:
1. email the professors you are interested to get interviews. Your salary will most likely depend on the funding situation of the professor.
2. Be very eager. Even if they did not reply or shows no interests, it is usually a good idea to knock on their door.
3. talk to professors, and if they are willing to hire you, your chance of getting admission is catapulted.
4. submit the whole application package to the department.
5. wait for admission, and need to constantly check with professor and remind them of your existence.
Interview Questions: Describe your research experience.

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in May 2010
Interview Descriptions: Steps includes emails,phone calls and face to face discussion by different peoples at different levels of positions in the lab. First a general background introduction is needed, then detailed  questions based on your CV will be asked and the numbers of  questions are depending on their satisfactions to your answers.Following this is specific technical questions concerning research experience, including how you solve problems based on your own capability. Finally is the future plan if you are hired and what requirements you have from the employer.
Interview Questions: what types of people you would like to become after a few years' work here?

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Apr 2010
Interview Descriptions: This required applying to the PhD program, so while there was not an interview process, per se, to be accepted into a PhD program entails talking with various professors about how your research interests match up with theirs, which sort of turn out to be informal interviews.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to do a PhD program?

Interview Descriptions:
1. applied for the job
2. was informed that they are interested in my CV 
3. set up a date for interview via skype as I was in India 
4. gave presentation on skype for an hour 
5. informed me that they will let me know in a months period
6. nearly in a month I was informed that they are ready to hire me.
Interview Questions: all questions were related to my field of work

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Mar 2010
Interview Descriptions: I worked with my advisor for a quarter and then he hired me. there was no formal interview, only a discussion of interests. The hiring depended on the funding he had at that point. He had obtained a project at that point which was of my interest as well. I joined his group in the summer.
Interview Questions: There was no interview, but I worked on a project for which I had no background. So there is a learning curve involved. this seasoned me for the type of projects that we would work on.

title: Graduate Student Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Feb 2010
Interview Descriptions: phone call interview for you to talk about your research interests and experiences. You get to know more about the PhD requirements and lab cultures through the phone call as well
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at UCLA (Los Angeles, CA) in Feb 2010
Interview Descriptions: I contacted the professor I wanted to work with by email to ask about available postdoctoral scholar positions. The professor had funding and asked me to have my references letters sent to him. I was then invited out for an interview, I scheduled the interview about 4 weeks after I initially contacted the professor. The interview involved me giving a presentation on my PhD research to the research group, then a 1:1 meeting with the professor. Then I went to lunch with the professor and some group members. Later I talked to some group members about their research. The day was over by the early afternoon. It took a week before the professor contacted me to offer me the job.
Interview Questions: Are you used to working under a lot of pressure?

title: Tour Guide Interview
